remarks: An ordered pair theorem for nonnegative integers.  Theorem 17.3 of [Quine] p. 124.  We can represent an ordered pair of nonnegative integers ` A ` and ` B ` by ` ( ( ( A + B ) x. ( A + B ) ) + B ) ` .  If two such ordered pairs are equal, their first elements are equal and their second elements are equal.  Contrast this ordered pair representation with the standard one ~ df-op that works for any set. (Contributed by Raph Levien, 10-Dec-2002.)  (Proof shortened by Scott Fenton, 8-Sep-2010.)
statement:
nn0opth.1 $e |- A e. NN0 $.
nn0opth.2 $e |- B e. NN0 $.
nn0opth.3 $e |- C e. NN0 $.
nn0opth.4 $e |- D e. NN0 $.
nn0opthi $p |- ( ( ( ( A + B ) x. ( A + B ) ) + B ) = ( ( ( C + D ) x. ( C + D ) ) + D ) <-> ( A = C /\ B = D ) ) $.
